In the Middle East, distribution of the film became a political issue due to homosexuality being considered a crime in most Islamic nations and being taboo in the few countries where it is legal. The film, titled 'Brokeback Mountain', was dubbed 'the gay cowboy movie' by the press, propelled into the American vernacular.
The film was not shown in theaters in China, though it was freely available in bootleg DVD and VHS. The Chinese government accused censorship as the audience would have been too small.
The film, titled 'Brokeback Mountain', has also entered the Chinese lexicon as a slang for homosexuality due to its portrayal of same-sex relationships.

In response to being celebrated in China for winning the Best Director Academy Award, Ang Lee stated that the film was not released there due to mixed responses in some regions, particularly China and Islamic nations of western Asia.

Gene Shalit, a film critic from The Today Show, described Jack Twist as a 'sexual predator' in his review of Brokeback Mountain. GLAAD compared this characterization to calling Jack in Titanic a sexual predator due to his romantic pursuit of Rose.
Gene Shalit described how Jack Twist 'tracks Ennis down' and coaxes him into sporadic trysts in his review of Brokeback Mountain.

The LGBTQ media group GLAAD accused Gene Shalit of having an 'unpopular opinion' in his review of Brokeback Mountain, and questioned whether he was a homophobe. However, Peter Shalit, Gene's openly gay son, defended him against this accusation.

Gene Shalit later apologized for his review of Brokeback Mountain, stating that he did not intend to use a word that many in the gay community consider incendiary and that he had no intention of casting aspersions on anyone in the gay community or on the community itself. He regretted any emotional hurt that may have resulted from his review.

The film portrays a same-sex relationship between Ennis and Jack, with some commentators accusing the filmmakers of hiding their relationship in advertising and public events. Brokeback Mountain, a critically acclaimed film, has been recognized as a landmark in the genre of LGBT cinema. Its success has led to increased funding and support for new gay-themed projects, challenging stereotypical representations and paving the way for films such as Milk, Transamerica, and I Love You Phillip Morris.

As a result of Brokeback Mountain's success, major film studios have shown increased interest in funding and supporting new gay-themed projects, as recognized by Steven Paul Davies in Out at the Movies.
